questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds

options.label: C
options.text: Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.correct_answer: C. Taking CT scan of the patient
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Taking CT scan of the patient

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary survey in trauma care includes Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure/Environmental control. Advanced imaging studies like CT scans are part of the secondary survey, conducted after initial stabilization.

questions.text: Iron absorption is decreased by the intake of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tea

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • There are several factors that can decrease iron absorption, including phytates (present in cereals and legumes), tannates (present in tea, coffee, and soft drinks), oxalates (present in milk and eggs), and certain medications like tetracycline.
  • • including phytates (present in cereals and legumes), tannates (present in tea, coffee, and soft drinks), oxalates (present in milk and eggs), and certain medications like tetracycline.
  • • The only facilitator of iron absorption is vitamin C or ascorbic acid.
  • • Among the given options, tea contains tannates, which are known to inhibit iron absorption. Therefore, the intake of tea decreases iron absorption.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Amla: This option is incorrect because amla is a rich source of vitamin C, which enhances iron absorption.
  • • Option
  • • A. Amla:
  • • Option B. Sprouts: This option is incorrect because sprouts are a good source of iron.
  • • Option
  • • B. Sprouts:
  • • Option D. Lemon: This option is incorrect because lemon is a source of vitamin C, which facilitates iron absorption.
  • • Option
  • • D. Lemon:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tea contains tannates, which are compounds that inhibit iron absorption. Consuming tea can decrease the absorption of iron from dietary sources.

questions.text: A dead body is recovered from a river. The body has signs of antemortem drowning and also has multiple wounds as shown below. What can be the cause of these wounds? (FMGE 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Self-inflicted

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows multiple superficial, parallel incised wounds on the forearm, which are characteristic of hesitation marks. Hesitation marks are typically seen in cases of suicide attempts where the individual makes multiple superficial cuts while hesitating to make a final, deeper cut.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Active self-defense wound: Incorrect because active self-defense wounds are found on the front of the hands and forearms and usually involve a struggle, not multiple, superficial, parallel cuts.
  • • Option B. Active self-defense wound:
  • • Option C. Postmortem artifact: Incorrect because postmortem artifacts do not present as multiple, organized, parallel incised wounds.
  • • Option C. Postmortem artifact:
  • • Option D. Passive self-defense wound: Incorrect because passive self-defense wounds are found on the back of the hands and forearms and are typically blunt force injuries, not superficial cuts.
  • • Option D. Passive self-defense wound:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Key points to understand about the different types of wounds:
  • ➤ Key points to understand about the different types of wounds:

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with lesion in tibial diaphysis. Histopathological examination is shown in below given image. On IHC, it was MIC-2 positive and synaptophysin positive cells. Most likely diagnosis will be: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.
  • ➤ The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text: Identify this instrument: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Verres needle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The instrument shown in the image is a Verres needle, which is commonly used in laparoscopic surgeries to create pneumoperitoneum. Pneumoperitoneum is the introduction of gas, typically carbon dioxide, into the peritoneal cavity. This step is crucial as it provides the necessary space for the surgeon to visualize and operate within the abdomen.
  • • The Verres needle is inserted into the abdominal cavity, and once its correct placement is confirmed, carbon dioxide is introduced through the needle to inflate the peritoneal cavity.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Leech Wilkinson cannula : This is not typically used for creating pneumoperitoneum.
  • • Option A. Leech Wilkinson cannula
  • • Option C. Laparoscope : This is an instrument used for visual inspection of the abdominal cavity but is introduced after pneumoperitoneum is established.
  • • Option C. Laparoscope
  • • Option D. Trocar and cannula : These are used for the insertion of various instruments into the abdomen during laparoscopic surgery, but the creation of pneumoperitoneum is done first using the Verres needle.
  • • Option D. Trocar and cannula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Verres needle is essential for creating pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries, allowing for the necessary space for safe and effective surgical procedures within the abdominal cavity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV-positive male arrives at the hospital complaining of blurred vision and floaters in his left eye. Fundus examination reveals a pizza pie appearance and cotton wool spots, leading to a diagnosis of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ganciclovir is the most appropriate treatment for cytomegalovirus retinitis in HIV-positive patients, as it effectively inhibits CMV replication and helps preserve vision.

questions.text: The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein with N-terminal facing cytoplasm is located in? (INICET May 2022)

options.label: D
options.text: Both inside the membrane and at C- terminal

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Inside the membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is located inside the membrane, crucial for the proper orientation and insertion of the protein.

questions.text: Grievous hurt under Section 320 IPC include all except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 7 days admission in hospital

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Grievous hurt under IPC 320 involves injuries that cause permanent disability, severe bodily pain, or life-altering effects. Hospital stay duration alone does not qualify an injury as grievous hurt unless accompanied by a severe or specified injury under the law.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of fatigue, lethargy, pallor, and right index finger pain. Biochemical analysis showed raised indirect bilirubin. What can be the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sickle cell anemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The combination of symptoms, including fatigue, lethargy, pallor (suggesting anemia), right index finger pain, and elevated indirect bilirubin levels (indicating jaundice), strongly points toward sickle cell anemia as the underlying diagnosis.
  • • Sickle cell anemia is a hemolytic anemia characterized by the production of abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells, which can lead to vaso-occlusive crises and ischemic damage.
  • • The presence of right index finger pain is a crucial clue, as it may be a manifestation of dactylitis or hand-foot syndrome, which is commonly seen in sickle cell anemia patients. This condition arises due to the involvement of small blood vessels in the hands and feet, leading to inflammation and severe pain.
  • • Additionally, the hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells) associated with sickle cell anemia results in anemia and elevated indirect bilirubin levels, causing jaundice.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Thalassemia: While thalassemia is also a type of hemolytic anemia, it does not typically present with the characteristic hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis seen in sickle cell anemia.
  • • Option B. Thalassemia:
  • • Option C. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves the destruction of red blood cells by the body's own immune system. It does not typically cause the specific symptom of index finger pain.
  • • Option C. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia:
  • • Option D. PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria): PNH is a rare acquired disorder characterized by the destruction of red blood cells, but it does not typically present with the combination of symptoms seen in this case, particularly the right index finger pain.
  • • Option D. PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with anemia, jaundice, and specific finger pain (dactylitis or hand-foot syndrome), sickle cell anemia should be strongly considered as the underlying diagnosis.

questions.text: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Loss of myelin sheath

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple sclerosis is characterized by demyelination that results in loss of saltatory conduction occurring from one node of Ranvier to the other .
  • ➤ demyelination that results in loss of saltatory conduction occurring from one node of Ranvier to the other

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Multiple sclerosis/Chap 444

questions.text: Identify the classification used and grade of the shown injury in a child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gartland’s classification Type III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Gartland classification is specifically used for supracondylar humerus fractures in children, while the Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate (epiphyseal) fractures.
  • ➤ Gartland classification
  • ➤ Salter-Harris classification
  • ➤ Gartland classification Supracondylar humerus
  • ➤ Gartland classification Supracondylar humerus
  • ➤ Type 1: Undisplaced Type 2: Displaced with posterior hinge intact Type 3a: Displaced fracture with lateral hinge broken (PM) Type 3b: Displaced fracture with medial hinge broken (PL) Type 4: Completely displaced with both anterior and posterior periosteum avulsed (Intra-operative finding)
  • ➤ Type 1: Undisplaced
  • ➤ Type 2: Displaced with posterior hinge intact
  • ➤ Type 3a: Displaced fracture with lateral hinge broken (PM)
  • ➤ Type 3b: Displaced fracture with medial hinge broken (PL)
  • ➤ Type 4: Completely displaced with both anterior and posterior periosteum avulsed (Intra-operative finding)
  • ➤ Salter-Harris classification of epiphyseal injuries
  • ➤ Salter-Harris classification of epiphyseal injuries
  • ➤ Type I: Fracture line is entirely with in Physis causing epiphyseal slip Type II: Fracture line extends from physis into the Metaphysis (Thurston-Holland’s fragment sign) Type III: Fracture line extends from physis into the Epiphysis causing epiphyseal split Type IV: Fracture line extends across the Epiphysis, (articular surface), Physis, and metaphysis Type V: Crush injury of physis with initially normal X-rays
  • ➤ Type I: Fracture line is entirely with in Physis causing epiphyseal slip
  • ➤ Type II: Fracture line extends from physis into the Metaphysis (Thurston-Holland’s fragment sign)
  • ➤ Type III: Fracture line extends from physis into the Epiphysis causing epiphyseal split
  • ➤ Type IV: Fracture line extends across the Epiphysis, (articular surface), Physis, and metaphysis
  • ➤ Type V: Crush injury of physis with initially normal X-rays

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old friend from the same school is afraid of contracting the disease. What advice should be given to the exposed students? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For immediate protection after exposure to meningococcal meningitis, antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary. Vaccination is also recommended but does not provide immediate protection.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating whether a correlation exists between CRP values and the likelihood of experiencing myocardial infarction or stroke. The participants in the study were split into five groups and the following table is formed based on the study results. Among the provided options, which statement accurately reflects the connection between CRP levels and the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke? (NEET PG 2021) (CRP à C-reactive protein)

options.label: A
options.text: CRP has no association with risk of MI/stroke

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Stroke

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in CRP decreases the risk of Ml/stroke

options.label: D
options.text: In group 1, there is no risk of MI/stroke

questions.correct_answer: B. Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Stroke
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Stroke

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Increased CRP levels are positively associated with an increased risk of myocardial infarction (MI) and stroke. As CRP levels rise, the relative risk of these conditions also increases.

questions.text: During the surgical procedure for patent ductus arteriosus, which structure in close relation to it can be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Left recurrent laryngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is at significant risk of injury during surgical procedures for patent ductus arteriosus due to its close anatomical relationship with the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: During the forensic examination of dry semen from undergarment of a rape victim. What specific test is employed to ascertain the presence of sperm? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Barberio test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When examining dry semen stains, such as those found on the undergarment of a rape victim, the Barberio test is the specific test employed to ascertain the presence of sperm, as it can yield positive results even in dry stains.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a history of chronic pulmonary aspergillosis is being treated with voriconazole. He has been on the medication for two weeks and comes to the clinic for a follow-up. During the visit, he asks about the specific guidelines and considerations for taking voriconazole to ensure its effectiveness and safety. Which of the following statements is true about voriconazole? ( INICET May 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: It should not be given with pyrazinamide

options.label: B
options.text: It should be taken empty stomach

options.label: C
options.text: It is given as a loading dose

questions.correct_answer: C. It is given as a loading dose
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is given as a loading dose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In summary, the statement that voriconazole "is given as a loading dose" is the most universally applicable and critical aspect of its administration, especially for ensuring rapid therapeutic levels in treating fungal infections.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the OPD with a painless, very slowly growing mass of the right third finger. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enchondroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enchondromas as painless, very slowly growing masses that commonly affect the short bones of the hand.
  • ➤ Enchondromas as painless, very slowly growing masses that commonly affect the short bones of the hand.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest X-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Streptococcus pneumoniae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with AIDS, Streptococcus pneumoniae remains the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia, regardless of the CD4 count. This should be a primary consideration when evaluating pneumonia in this population.

questions.text: Which of the following can grow in an acidic pH? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lactobacilli

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lactobacilli's ability to grow in acidic environments is crucial for their role in maintaining healthy microbial flora in certain parts of the human body, such as the vagina, and is also exploited in the fermentation of various food products.

questions.text: Bacillus anthracis is which category of bioweapon? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Category A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bacillus anthracis is classified as a Category A bioweapon due to its high potential for causing significant public health impact through easy dissemination and high mortality rates.

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding that cholera toxin acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors is crucial for grasping the pathophysiological basis of cholera. This interaction triggers a cascade of events leading to the massive, life-threatening secretory diarrhea that characterizes the disease. Proper hydration and antibiotics like erythromycin are key to treatment.

questions.text: Arrange the following steps of milk production in the correct sequence: (FMGE JANUARY 2024) Galactopoiesis Lactogenesis Mammogenesis Lactation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3, 2, 1, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct sequence of milk production involves several stages, starting from the development of the mammary glands to the actual ejection of milk. These stages are:
  • • 3. Mammogenesis : This is the development of the mammary glands , which begins at birth but continues significantly during puberty. The breast tissue matures and prepares for potential milk production.
  • • 3. Mammogenesis :
  • • development of the mammary glands
  • • 2. Lactogenesis : This stage refers to the initiation of milk synthesis . It involves hormonal changes that stimulate the mammary glands to start producing milk. Lactogenesis typically begins during the late stages of pregnancy and continues after childbirth.
  • • 2. Lactogenesis :
  • • initiation of milk synthesis
  • • 1. Galactopoiesis : This is the maintenance of milk production after lactogenesis has initiated. It involves the continued synthesis and secretion of milk, which is essential for sustaining milk supply during breastfeeding.
  • • 1. Galactopoiesis :
  • • maintenance of milk production
  • • 4. Lactation: This refers to the process of milk ejection and feeding the baby. It encompasses the baby's suckling, which stimulates further milk production and ejection through the let-down reflex.
  • • 4. Lactation:
  • • milk ejection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of milk production involves mammogenesis, lactogenesis, galactopoiesis, and finally lactation.

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee and a high fever. X-ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Aspirate from the joint will most likely show: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Salmonella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Acute osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is caused by salmonella.
  • ➤ Acute osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is caused by salmonella.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented after a motor vehicle accident to the emergency. On examination, the right lower limb was longer than the left, abducted and externally rotated. What can be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior hip dislocation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The limb appears lengthened and in FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation) deformity in anterior dislocation of the hip following a motor vehicle accident. Thus, in the given scenario, the patient has anterior dislocation of the hip.
  • ➤ The limb appears lengthened and in FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation) deformity in anterior dislocation of the hip following a motor vehicle accident.
  • ➤ Thus, in the given scenario, the patient has anterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: Which vector is responsible for transmitting Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mites.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scrub typhus, caused by Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi, is transmitted by the trombiculid mite, making mites the vector responsible for this disease.

questions.text: The structures marked in the image below are found in the epithelial lining of all of the following sites, except? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Epididymis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ciliated epithelium:
  • ➤ Ciliated epithelium:
  • ➤ The epithelium bears cilia, which moves in a coordinated fashion, and help in the movement of the mucus, or propel the movement of any other structures such as ova or spermatozoa. The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain. The pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is seen in the trachea and in large bronchi.
  • ➤ The epithelium bears cilia, which moves in a coordinated fashion, and help in the movement of the mucus, or propel the movement of any other structures such as ova or spermatozoa.
  • ➤ The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.
  • ➤ The pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is seen in the trachea and in large bronchi.

questions.text: A biostatistician is reviewing data from a recent research study. She observes that the confidence interval (CI) for one of the primary outcomes is quite wide. Which of the following factors is least likely to contribute to the widening of the confidence interval? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increasing sample size

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A smaller sample size or a higher variability will result in a wider confidence interval with a larger margin of error As sample size increases, the margin of error decreases As the variability in the population increases, the margin of error increases As you increase the confidence level (e.g., 95% to 99%) while holding the sample size and variability constant, the confidence interval widens Smaller the SD, narrower is Confidence interval
  • ➤ A smaller sample size or a higher variability will result in a wider confidence interval with a larger margin of error
  • ➤ As sample size increases, the margin of error decreases
  • ➤ As the variability in the population increases, the margin of error increases
  • ➤ As you increase the confidence level (e.g., 95% to 99%) while holding the sample size and variability constant, the confidence interval widens
  • ➤ Smaller the SD, narrower is Confidence interval

questions.text: A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate show the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical vignette of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance points to diagnosis of Gaucher's disease, in which enzyme deficient is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gaucher’s Disease
  • ➤ Gaucher’s Disease

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient has hypokalemia, hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. What is the most likely etiology? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Liddle’s Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Liddle's syndrome is characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis due to increased activity of sodium channels in the distal nephron, not due to increased aldosterone, distinguishing it from other similar electrolyte disorders.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21E/ Physiology of Kidney/Chap 309 - Table 309-1

questions.text: Anenecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in which week of gestation? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 4th week

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ananecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in 4 th week of gestation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the likely organism shown in the image below?

options.label: B
options.text: Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen

options.label: D
options.text: Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Most commonly affects lungs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Cryptococcus neoformans most commonly affects the lungs as the primary site of infection, followed by potential dissemination to other organs, especially the central nervous system.

questions.text: What information is conveyed by the graph presented below? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, skewed with outliers

options.label: B
options.text: Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers

options.label: C
options.text: Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, normal with outliers

options.label: D
options.text: Skewed with outliers, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal

questions.correct_answer: B. Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Box and Whisker plot
  • ➤ Box and Whisker plot
  • ➤ A graphical presentation of Numerical Data through its quartiles. It has a box in the center and two wishers in its sides. The box has got 2 ends, Quartile 1 (Q1) & Quartile 3 (Q3) The vertical line inside the box is called median also known as Q2. The whole data is divided into 4 Quartiles The lower end of one whisker represent the minimum value of the distribution. The higher end of other Whisker represents the maximum value of the distribution.
  • ➤ A graphical presentation of Numerical Data through its quartiles.
  • ➤ It has a box in the center and two wishers in its sides.
  • ➤ The box has got 2 ends, Quartile 1 (Q1) & Quartile 3 (Q3)
  • ➤ The vertical line inside the box is called median also known as Q2. The whole data is divided into 4 Quartiles
  • ➤ The lower end of one whisker represent the minimum value of the distribution.
  • ➤ The higher end of other Whisker represents the maximum value of the distribution.

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing district data to determine which areas should be prioritized for tuberculosis (TB) interventions. According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), which of the following HIV-TB prevalence rates would categorize a district as high-priority? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) >10%

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complains of ptosis and diplopia that worsens with activity and improves with rest. What is the most sensitive investigation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) EMG (Electromyography)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most sensitive investigation for diagnosing myasthenia gravis is electromyography (EMG), particularly single fiber EMG, which detects abnormalities in neuromuscular transmission.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dyspnea on exertion for 1 month. Echocardiography showed the presence of mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy. Identify the histopathological finding given below and the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.correct_answer: A. Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aschoff bodies are indicative of Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) , and their presence supports the diagnosis in a patient with clinical features such as mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy.
  • ➤ Aschoff bodies
  • ➤ Rheumatic heart disease (RHD)
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 1044
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 1044

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD. Her school going nephew who lives in the same house has contracted varicella. A blood sample is taken for Antibodies against varicella. The report is negative. What does this signify? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Susceptible to chicken pox

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Chickenpox in Pregnancy:
  • • Chickenpox in Pregnancy:
  • • Pregnant women with uncertain or no previous history of chickenpox, who have been exposed to the infection, should have a blood test to determine their immunity to Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV). A negative antibody test indicates that the woman is not immune to VZV and is susceptible to chickenpox. If a pregnant woman is not immune and has had significant exposure, she is at risk of developing chickenpox and should be administered varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG). VZIG is effective up to 10 days after contact. Symptomatic treatment of chickenpox in pregnancy includes: Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks. Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox. VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has started. Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection to look for congenital varicella syndrome. If the infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy, there is a risk of varicella infection in the newborn. Planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.
  • • Pregnant women with uncertain or no previous history of chickenpox, who have been exposed to the infection, should have a blood test to determine their immunity to Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV).
  • • A negative antibody test indicates that the woman is not immune to VZV and is susceptible to chickenpox.
  • • If a pregnant woman is not immune and has had significant exposure, she is at risk of developing chickenpox and should be administered varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG).
  • • VZIG is effective up to 10 days after contact.
  • • Symptomatic treatment of chickenpox in pregnancy includes: Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks. Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • • Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks. Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • • Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks.
  • • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has started.
  • • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection to look for congenital varicella syndrome.
  • • If the infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy, there is a risk of varicella infection in the newborn. Planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Immune to chickenpox: A negative antibody test does not signify immunity; it signifies susceptibility.
  • • Option B. Immune to chickenpox:
  • • Option C. Susceptible to zoster: Varicella-zoster virus causes both chickenpox (primary infection) and shingles (reactivation). A negative test for varicella antibodies indicates susceptibility to the primary infection (chickenpox), not to shingles.
  • • Option C. Susceptible to zoster:
  • • Option D. Immune to zoster: Immunity to zoster would imply prior exposure to the varicella-zoster virus, which is not indicated by a negative varicella antibody test.
  • • Option D. Immune to zoster:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative varicella antibody test in a pregnant woman indicates that she is susceptible to chickenpox and should receive VZIG if exposed.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 3085, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A cohort study was carried out involving individuals who consumed green tea and those who did not, aiming to examine its impact on diabetes mellitus. The calculated risk ratio stood at 0.84. Which of the subsequent statements is accurate? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Green tea increases the risk of diabetes

options.label: B
options.text: Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes

options.label: C
options.text: Data insufficient to establish causal association

options.label: D
options.text: The value (0.84) tends to be close to 1, hence there is no effect

questions.correct_answer: B. Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed
  • ➤ Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed
  • ➤ Note - Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:– Relative risk, Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR)
  • ➤ Note - Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:– Relative risk, Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR)

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic came with complaints of agitation, disorientation, hallucination, fever, hypertension, and diaphoresis after stopping alcohol intake for 48 hours. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delirium tremens is a severe, life-threatening form of alcohol withdrawal that occurs 48 to 96 hours after cessation of alcohol intake, characterized by autonomic instability, agitation, disorientation, and hallucinations. The first-line treatment is benzodiazepines, particularly diazepam.
  • ➤ severe, life-threatening

questions.text: A patient with a mood disorder has been on medication and presents with new-onset liver dysfunction and hyperammonemia. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Valproate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Valproate can cause hepatotoxicity and hyperammonemia, making it the most likely culprit in patients presenting with these conditions while on medication for mood disorders.

questions.text: Cowden syndrome is associated with mutation in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PTEN
